Fields.DialogueText: You look like you're enjoying yourself, Axum.
Whenever we surface the submarine, I always make sure to enjoy the sunshine, Capitano.
It *is* nice after being underwater for so long.
This is a chance for the crew to get some fresh air as well.
Noted. I'll try to get as many of our crew some time to relax topside before we dive again.
Mille grazie, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: I have to say, I think my tolerance for being underwater ran out about four hours before we surfaced today.
That said, a submarine's proper place is beneath the waves. No point in pretending otherwise.
We're not safe on the surface.

Fields.DialogueText: I do empathize, Capitano. And I try to make it as comfortable as possible for you.
Actually, I'm comfortable above and below the surface.
We are not as stealthy, but I promise I will never let down my guard.
That said, we can't avoid coming up now and then to run our diesel engines and charge the batteries.
Make sure to get a full charge. I want to maximize our endurance.
Of course, Capitano. We will be ready for any-
... Go on. I'm braced for it.
I believe I've spotted some trouble on the horizon.
So much for basking in the sun!
@BATTLE
I'm pretty confident that a woken Belle makes the air in a sealed sub smell about 400% better than it otherwise would. You're doing your part.
Grazie.
Heh. Noted.
I really don't appreciate interruptions.
Forgive me, Capitano! I was just bringing you some coffee...
I wasn't talking about you, Axum. I was referring to the Morganas who interrupted our time on the surface.
Oh! Of course, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: I apologize for not making myself clear.
Do you take everything so personally?
You said something about coffee?

Fields.DialogueText: Think nothing of it, Capitano.
I was just making sure I did not give offense.
I did.
You know I value our working relationship, Capitano. I wouldn't want a miscommunication to jeopardize that relationship.
Pf. Me? You're the one who never loses her self-possession - even in combat.
I'd like to think especially in combat, Capitano.
Yeah. Good point.
*ALARM*
*slurps the rest of the coffee down*
@BATTLE
Thoughtful as always, Axum.
I understand - but there's really no need to be insecure. We've been through dozens of battles together. And a really, really awkward dinner.
"You can't outglare me."
Is that what I said?
I think so. That or something similarly inspirational.
Well, I had coffee to keep me strong.
No. You're just always composed. It's downright uncanny.
*raises cup in salute*
I'll meet you on the bridge!
Go!
We'll be ready to dive again soon. Do you see anything on the horizon?
I sense no other vessels out here, but I'm still scanning. Here, take my binoculars, Capitano.
You don't want them?
I often do better without them. I prefer to use my eyes without assistance.
I'm officially impressed. You're every bit the huntress.
Grazie, Capitano. I do my best.

Fields.MenuText: You seem to really enjoy prowling around for Morganas.
Is there a reason why you seem a little more intense up here today?
Are you looking out for Morganas or... for something else?

Fields.DialogueText: A Belle should take pride in doing her job well. The same goes for all of our sailors, does it not?
At sea, Capitano, vigilance is always a necessity. In war, doubly so.
I am watching for anything that might be out of place.
The Morganas are unnatural, Capitano. Even without a war or without orders from Command, it would still be imperative to hunt them down.
Hunt them to extinction, I hope.
I hope so, too.
I suspect we'll have plenty of chances...
@BATTLE
Axum! To the bridge!
Reporting as ordered, Capitano.
We have orders. Take a look.
Urgent deployment to the Aegean.
Mm-hm. Sparse on details, though I think we can make an educated guess. Lots of little islands the Morganas can haunt.
Is something wrong?
I suppose we should prepare ourselves to relocate, then.

Fields.MenuText: Why do you seem hesitant? Is there a problem?
You seem reluctant to leave Africa.
Those orders don't seem like a surprise to you.

Fields.DialogueText: No problem at all, Capitano. I am always ready to embrace a new opportunity.
I enjoyed being close to home, but I knew that eventually we would have to go to wherever the war needed us.
I have been expecting that we make our way toward Greece eventually.
It was only a matter of time, Capitano, before the operatives there would need our assistance.
Operatives? What are you talking about?
This may take some time to explain, Capitano. It-
*ALARM*
Right. Well, that time isn't now - but fill me in later.
Of course.
@BATTLE
We are submerged. All stations report conditions normal on the dive.
Thank you, Axum.
Will that be all, Capitano?
Not quite. Shut the door behind you, please.
Certo, Capitano.
Now, about these "operatives" you mentioned before...

Fields.MenuText: Why are you being so secretive about all of this?
Who are they?
You should not withhold information from your commanding officer.

Fields.DialogueText: It is a sensitive matter, Capitano.
The operatives are involved in a highly sensitive mission, Capitano.
I apologize, Capitano, but I had to wait until we had adequate privacy.
Special forces commandos have been stranded in Greece. Command needs a covert way to extract them.
And a submarine is the ideal platform to do it.
I cannot disagree with that.
Okay, next question. How did you know about this? Belle gossip, or-
No, no. It's simpler than that, Capitano.
I was the one who stranded them there.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Lieutenant, when you have a minute, show me how we're getting through these rocks.
Can I be of assistance, Capitano?
I was checking our course into the Aegean. With all of these small islands and rocky formations, there's a lot to keep track of.
I will be happy to help. I have some familiarity with this location.
Right. You've been here before.

Fields.MenuText: Why are you so quiet all of a sudden? You're not in trouble.
Is there something I should know before we get there?
Out with it.

Fields.DialogueText: The matter is a complicated one, but I will try to keep my feelings from interfering, Capitano.
I apologize for putting you in a difficult position, Capitano.
I promise to be forthcoming, Capitano. But this is just... a bit public, still.
When you're done checking the navigation charts, we should talk a little bit more. In private. If your schedule allows?
Fair enough.
But right now I need to finish my inspection of the torpedoes in the forward compartment.
Right. Carry on - I'll find you later.
Yeah, this is going to come back to bite us in the-
*ALARM*
Damn!
@BATTLE
Axum? Are you still down here in the torpedo room?
Sì, Capitano. Our torpedo inventory is satisfactory, and our torpedo tube hydraulics are in excellent shape.
Glad to hear it.
We are alone down here for now. Perhaps we could discuss the mission.
I've been waiting for the right time. This whole thing...

Fields.MenuText: ... makes me concerned about your well-being.
... makes me wonder if we're heading into trouble.
... makes me question our working relationship.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate that, Capitano.
We could be, but not just because of Morganas.
Perhaps, when I tell you more, it will explain my awkwardness.
Before we began working together, Capitano, I took part in a mission with a force of special commandos in the Aegean Sea.
What were the commandos supposed to do?
Their mission was to infiltrate the Greek islands and establish a secret observation post for scouting enemy movements.
By "enemy," you mean Morganas? Or a more exclusively Italian concern?
That... is the sensitive part. While the Morganas are the common enemy of all nations, other alliances are not so clear.
Right. And after Italy annexed Albania, I assume the Greeks haven't been too-
Somebody's coming.
Captain? Are you down here?
Aye.
Oh, Miss Axum! You're both here. We've detected a possible threat. You are requested on the bridge at once.
Tell them I'm on my way.
Aye aye, Capitano.
We're obviously going to have to get back to this later.
Certamente. For now, let's get to the bridge and deal with the threat.
@BATTLE
Capitano?
Come in, and close the door behind you.
Before we make contact with the commandos in Greece, I need to understand the whole situation.
As I was trying to explain earlier in the torpedo room, I was part of a mission to covertly deploy special forces personnel to Greece.
They were tasked with reporting Morgana movements, but also observing the activity of naval forces in the area. To ensure they were complying with Protection Force guidelines.
Sorry. When was the last time you heard from them?
They sent a coded emergency message some time ago, but Command wouldn't let me help them.
They didn't want you to compromise the mission?
I suspect that was the main reason, Capitano.
I think I understand.

Fields.MenuText: You feel guilty about how this has played out.
You think some members of the crew will be upset if they learn Command thinks their home nations untrustworthy.
You think we're walking into trouble.

Fields.DialogueText: I... know it's not reasonable. But, you're right. Those men were in my care, if only for a while, and I do feel responsible for them.
We have crew members from many different backgrounds. Divided loyalties could cause problems.
I'm not afraid of a fight.
I brought them to Greece, so I want to support them.
Right. I get that.
I wish I knew.
Maybe they found something big.
*ALARM*
And something else has found us.
@BATTLE
Delicately put.
Capitano...
Obvious question: if Command wouldn't let you help before, why are they sending us in now? What's changed?
Morgana patrol sighted!
@BATTLE
Buongiorno, Capitano!
Happy to be in the sunshine again, I see.
Oh, yes. Capitano, smell that air! The Mediterranean blesses us with fair winds and following seas today.
So it does. This is... really, really welcome.
I... also feel much better after finally telling you about the commandos. You didn't have need to know before, so I couldn't, but...
Well, don't get too relaxed here. The mission could still be quite dangerous.
Certo - but we can and will overcome that. If a Belle and her capitano are aligned, success follows.

Fields.MenuText: Ever the optimist.
If I didn't know you better, I'd think you were being overconfident.
Make sure we stay aligned. No secrets.

Fields.DialogueText: A bright outlook can win the day.
I should hope you know me perfectly well.
Agreed.
I am not a fast vessel, Capitano. We still have plenty of time before we reach Greece.
Then let's enjoy the good parts.
You're going to say coffee.
See that? Belle and Capitano perfectly aligned.
Even more than you realize. I brought two cups, Capitano.
Mille grazie, Axum.
I've always admired your gift for understatement.
It was weighing on you?
Sì.
You know what would make this even better?
We are getting closer to the Aegean Sea, Capitano.
It feels like it's taking forever.
If we sprint, we would exhaust a great deal of our fuel for only a modest gain in speed. I am minding our endurance.
I know. And I know you have more invested than anyone else onboard in getting this done. I can't imagine you're enjoying the waiting either.
Have a look off the port beam, Capitano. Loggerhead turtles.
Where? I don't see anything. My eyes aren't as sharp as yours.
Look where I am pointing, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: Look at it! It's bigger than I expected.
It's strange to see turtles swimming in the middle of the sea.
Okay, maybe you *are* enjoying the waiting.

Fields.DialogueText: Nearly a meter long, some of them.
They have a reason for it.
Scusami, but loggerhead turtles are more than a mere curiosity, Capitano.
Loggerhead turtles are migratory. They must conserve their strength to travel long distances, too.
I see your point.
Oh! The turtles suddenly scattered.
Did they sense something we haven't noticed yet?
I suppose that's possible...
@BATTLE
*shrugs*
We're making good progress, Capitano.
Slow and steady, Axum. I don't want us hitting rocks while we're creeping around underwater.
Capisco. We're all being careful.
By the way, have you noticed? It's quite noisy in the water today.
I'm just hearing the usual ship noises. Sorry.
*SQUEAK*
... Okay, I'm impressed on a number of levels.

Fields.MenuText: Is somebody trying to communicate with us?
Whatever it is, it sounds rusty. Have the mechanics put some grease on it.
A few dolphins decided to keep us company?

Fields.DialogueText: In a manner of speaking, sì.
Haha! That would be quite comical, Capitano!
I believe so, Capitano.
Dolphins...
Despite Morganas and war, the sea is still full of life. It's comforting, no?
Mm. At the risk of sounding like a career officer... is there any way we can use this? Dolphins as an early-warning system?
It's not like I communicate with them in any meaningful way, Capitano. Maybe one day I'll learn how, but I'm not there yet.
Well, until then, I'll just trust the instincts of my Belle. Thank you for this, by the way.
Sì. It was certainly a... ah.
@BATTLE
What do you mean?
I do not think dolphins would tolerate being greased.
*ALARM*
My instincts say there are Morganas on the way.
Very funny.
Hold on. Let me dampen things for just a second and maybe I can help you hear...
We are navigating around Crete to the west, Capitano.
We're almost to the target zone, then.
È corretto. Our friends in the radio room are listening for further instructions... or calls for help.
You anticipated my orders, Axum.
Oh! I hope you don't mind.

Fields.MenuText: Of course not.
Just let me know before doing anything irreversible.
Don't get too far ahead of me, Axum.

Fields.DialogueText: Grazie, Capitano.
I promise that I would not engage in combat or release torpedoes without your command, Capitano.
Forgive me if I overstepped my station, Capitano.
I do endeavor to anticipate your commands.
I suppose that intuition is valuable for any good hunter.
È vero. A hunter must be able to anticipate the aspects of a hunt, to avoid losing precious time or making a critical error.
We also have to be flexible when the unexpected happens.
We will be.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
It's a little bit strange, isn't it?
What's that, Capitano?
A submariner's life under the waves.
I suppose it could be, compared to other ways of life. What specifically do you mean?
Well, here we are. A warship, a technological marvel in itself, crawling around underwater...
Sì, at about five knots.
In the middle of a global war, hiding from Morgana patrols, making our way to rendezvous with covert operatives...
And?
All while drinking a cup of coffee, making comfortable conversation with the most polite and poised Belle in the Regia Marina.
Haha! When you put it that way, it does seem a bit odd. And also, kind.
It is odd.

Fields.MenuText: We're too relaxed. We should be more careful.
I suppose I shouldn't question the luxuries that come our way.
It makes me glad that I'm not a grunt with a rifle somewhere.

Fields.DialogueText: I respectfully offer a different perspective, Capitano.
The things that give us pleasure and peace are not frivolous, Capitano.
I hold infantry in high regard for what they must endure, but I am far better suited to submarine warfare.
To return to an old metaphor: a hunter has to control her breathing to shoot accurately. Finding calm amidst difficulty provides considerable advantage.
If gourmet coffee is going to help us win the war, how can I refuse it?
Take strength from wherever we can find it.
And enjoy the good things in life while they last.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Sorry. I was asking for trouble there.
Just finish your coffee, Capitano. I'll meet you on the bridge.
*sigh*
Morgana patrol ahead!
@BATTLE
Helm, mind your rudder. We have to drive the straight and narrow to get safely past these islands.
Aye aye, Capitano.
Navigating here is hazardous. How can I assist?

Fields.MenuText: Check the navigator's charts to make sure our course is free of shoal water.
Get the helm some coffee to make sure they are alert.
Take the periscope for a bit.

Fields.DialogueText: Carelessly running aground on a shallow spot that we could have avoided would indeed be unfortunate. I will verify the navigator's plot.
Consider it done, Capitano.
Of course, Capitano.
There's danger in any number of these small, rocky islands sticking out of the water...
Especially the ones that aren't sticking out, but lying unseen just beneath the surface.
My hull is strong, but I would not want to test it against a pile of rocks.
Let me see...
What is it?
Recommend reducing the bell.
Very well. Slow the engines down to bare steerageway. Are we about to hit something?
Not exactly, Capitano. If I am not mistaken, something is about to hit us.
Axum, if you know something I don't, I would rather that you just tell me—
*KNOCK*
Damn! If my ears are not mistaken, something did hit us.
That's our signal. Let's surface the ship and open the hatch.
To check for damage?
Negative, Capitano. To let our visitor aboard.
We are surfaced, and the hatch is open.
Very well.
Permission to come aboard, Capitano?
Granted. Axum, help our guest aboard.
At once.
Welcome to--
This ship seems familiar, but the captain's face does not. I'm Bruno, Capitano.
Good to meet you. It's not every day that a swimmer finds their way aboard.
Miss Belle, I hope you didn't mind me knocking with a hammer to signal you.
I was sure my hammering couldn't damage your... magnificent hull.
Think nothing of--
Good. I won't.

Fields.MenuText: Please treat my Belle with a bit more courtesy, Bruno.
Right. Let's get you cleaned up.
You must be tired from your swim.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. Forgive my poor manners. Scusami, Capitano.
I would appreciate whatever hospitality you can afford me, even aboard a cramped submarine.
Sì, that is quite true.
Being stranded on an island and finding hostility on all sides must have exhausted me.
Axum, can you accommodate Bruno and ready him for a briefing?
Axum?
Of course, Capitano.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Command has acknowledged our report, Capitano. We are to assist Bruno in locating and rescuing the other commandos.
I hope Bruno can tell us where to find them, then.
I hope so too.
You certainly seemed uncomfortable when Bruno arrived.
A bit. The whole business reminds me of the terrible things those people must have endured after I delivered them to Greece.
It wasn't your fault that they were stranded.
It was still frustrating that Command would not let me extract them. Bruno must hold me responsible.

Fields.MenuText: I don't know about that. But you might be a convenient person to blame.
That's his problem.
I won't let him give you any trouble.

Fields.DialogueText: I understand. I blame myself.
That may be so, but it is difficult for me to ignore.
Mille grazie, Capitano. I am glad you are my ally in this.
I feel that the best way forward is to do everything we can to help those stranded people.
I can agree to that.
I will notify you as soon as Bruno is ready for debriefing.
Thank you, Axum.
I have a lot of questions that need to be answered...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Well, don't.
Hm.
Things became difficult soon after we disembarked from the submarine and attempted to infiltrate the Greek islands.
Were you able to establish an observation post?
Negative, Capitano. Soon after we swam ashore, we found the environment to be quite... hostile.
Would you care for some coffee?
No. Now, if I may continue?
I'll have some coffee, Axum.
Of course, Capitano.
As I was saying, we had problems as soon as we were on land. We could not locate the contact in Greece that Command told us to find.
Why not?
I am not certain, but I suspect our contact was killed before we even arrived.

Fields.MenuText: And you think he - or she - was betrayed.
Maybe they went to the wrong location.
Curious.

Fields.DialogueText: That is my fear.
We searched extensively for weeks with no luck.
Indeed.
Regardless, we were stranded and had to stay in hiding.
Were you able to gather any intelligence at all?
Hardly. We were too busy foraging and trying to stay alive. It was only after we finally stole a radio that we were able to contact Command for a rescue.
And we came as soon as Command sent us.
Hm. It seemed like a long time. Who was it at Command that dispatched you?
I don't know if--
*ALARM*
We'll have to continue this later. We have Morganas approaching.
Of course, Capitano.
Axum, let's get going.
At once, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Hiding from the Greeks? Or from the sea?
Capitano, where we were... the damned mist was everywhere, you understand? And it's poison. It can make a healthy man sick, and children? The old? It's just murder.
You had reason to believe that was happening out here?
Let's say we had no reason to believe that we would be welcomed with open arms. It was just a matter of how messy it could get.
And since we believed our contact had been eliminated...
I understand.
And just controlling them outright. On these little islands, there aren't so many places you can go if you need to escape from the sea.
I'm sure you've heard the rumors - Morganas offering civilians "protection" from the fumes in exchange for favors.
That was a strange debriefing with Bruno.
Agreed. And you clearly make him uneasy. I hope it's not-
Not that, Capitano. Bruno was not part of the team of commandos that I brought to Greece.
Hm.
I don't want to be impolite, but I don't trust him.
I don't either.
What makes you say that?

Fields.MenuText: His bona fides seem a little too... polished. And his story is vague.
He asked us to identify people at Command by name.
Bruno refused your coffee.

Fields.DialogueText: I take your point.
I noticed that as well. What a strange thing to ask!
There is no accounting for taste, Capitano.
Keep a close eye on Bruno. Don't let him into radio or other sensitive areas of the submarine.
Capisco, Capitano. I understand.
Be careful, Axum. We still have our orders from Command, but we have to be smart.
When are we not? We'll get to the bottom of this, Capitano.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Morgana convoy detected!
@BATTLE
Any difficulty in navigating the waters, Axum?
So far I have had no trouble, but some of the straits are becoming perilously narrow. I encouraged the quartermaster to stay alert.
Well done. We have to be careful out here.
It will only get more difficult the closer we get. It makes me wonder... how was Bruno able to swim out to us in waters like this?

Fields.MenuText: Commandos are legendary swimmers. He's trained to be indestructible.
Maybe he was able to make a raft. Commandos are good at improvising.
He was lucky?

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose that's possible.
That is probably true.
I have survived battles thanks to no small amount of luck, I suppose.
I don't like being so suspicious, but I keep thinking we're heading into a trap.
I trust your instincts, Axum. We'll be careful.
Aye aye, Capitano.
Axum, please report to the radio room.
Is it a message from Command?
Yes. They gave us a new search area for the commandos.
Let me see...
I'll have the navigator plot a course immediately. No matter how we feel about Bruno, those commandos need to be rescued quickly.
Of course.
Hello.
Scusi, signor.
Is there any new information? How soon can we get to the commando camp?

Fields.MenuText: We're plotting a course now.
Please let us take care of that.
You don't have access to this part of the ship, Bruno.

Fields.DialogueText: Molto bene, Capitano.
You must understand that we both want the same thing, Capitano.
Forgive me, Capitano.
I am just eager to know if we will be rescuing your friends soon.
Mm.
I... meant "our friends," of course. Forgive me - I haven't been sleeping so well...
*ALARM*
Please return to your berth. Axum and I have some business to take care of.
Morganas?
Yes. Now please, get going.
@BATTLE
I think I recognize that little island. We aren't far away now.
Give me back the periscope, Bruno.
It's quite treacherous in these straits.
Agreed. This is a terrible place to get caught in a storm... or an ambush.
We must keep going. You have the coordinates, yes?
Which is why none of the rendezvous coordinates you gave us between here and where we picked you up checked out, I suppose.
How dare you? I... I admit I'm confused! But to call me a liar? I'll report you! I'll-
No need to lose your temper.
I'll have him detained in the galley, Capitano.
What?! No! You have to take me closer to find them... rescue them...
I've heard enough. Get him out of here.
With pleasure.
A spy... What is he trying to do?
*ALARM*
Not now!
@BATTLE
Mm. This is close to where you were separated from the group, then?
Fairly close.
I'm surprised you can't find your own designated extraction point, mind you. Your commanding officer's going to rap your knuckles for that one.
It's hard to recognize landmarks from the water. You understand.
Excuses go over well in your unit? As a rule?
Ha! I suppose not.
Anyway, that should be our target over there. You see it? The cove?
Ah, yes! Of course! You see that rock formation? That's exactly what....
Nope.
What?
Sorry. That was a bald-faced lie. If you were a real member of the commando team, you'd know. It seemed like a good idea to take a little detour.
Have a final damage report for me, Axum?
We're lucky. No major damage from that last attack - but it could have easily been fatal.
Agreed. Do you think Bruno was signaling our location somehow? Or did we just stumble into a random monster pack?
But I doubt that "Bruno" is even his real name.

Fields.MenuText: I wonder who that bastard's working for.
Well, he was either going to signal our enemies - somehow - or he was going to lead us into some sort of kill box in the end.
I wonder if he's being forced into this.

Fields.DialogueText: It is hard to say. Italia has made many enemies for herself in the last few years.
I think you're right.
I highly doubt it.
You don't think there's even a remote chance he can lead us to the commando team, though?
None at all. I am finally cured of that delusion.
Good. Me, too.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
... I don't know.
Well, if he's Greek, I'm not too worried about him as an ongoing threat. If he's an agent of the Morganas...
*sigh*
I have transmitted our situation report to Command as you ordered.
Thanks. Maybe they can help us sort out what the hell is going on. We still have a commando team out here that's unaccounted for, and the last search area was a bust.
Of that, I am keenly aware.
Is our friend still tied up in his berth?
Indeed. "Bruno" is safely contained for now.
We don't have a brig, so that will have to do.
What team is he playing for?

Fields.MenuText: Greece?
Morganas?
A personal grudge?

Fields.DialogueText: Several Greek factions could have taken umbrage to commandos spying on their land.
Morganas employing human agents? That would be...terrifying.
I consider that unlikely. He seemed too... professional.
Italy has so many enemies, and only a handful of fickle alliances.
We have a great deal to resolve if we ever hope to find a way out of that conflict.
Ending the land war is good, but surviving the war at sea comes first. Stay alert for a major Morgana presence.
Aye aye, Capitano.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Command just confirmed it.
I don't expect I will like whatever you are about to tell me.
Sorry, Axum. Command says that a reconnaissance plane found the remains of the commando unit.
Remains. They perished, then.
Some of them, certainly. It's possible some escaped, but there's no sign of them now.
Again, I'm sorry. It seems the deceased were killed shortly after you took them to Greece.
At least we know why they died, and we know that "Bruno" is a spy.
I have a theory. The man's not talking, so I haven't confirmed it, but...
Yeah. But we're still here, and we have a prisoner.

Fields.MenuText: He must have intelligence on Morganas in this area.
We need to get out of here. The sooner this guy's in Italy the better.
So I'm afraid we can't just throw him overboard.

Fields.DialogueText: If he was their agent, that would certainly follow.
I concur, Capitano.
Don't look so glum.
Ah! I should not have let developments distract me. We are still at a tactical disadvantage in these straits.
Get us turned around and start heading south to open waters.
I... At once, Capitano.
I sense it, too.
*ALARM*
Damn!
@BATTLE
Go on.
I think the commandos saw something they shouldn't have. Morgana bombers got them, but the Morganas themselves couldn't be sure.
So they got creative, and wedged a human agent into our rescue mission.
If we had found any of them alive... well, I'm guessing Bruno's job was to keep them from reporting what they saw.
There's a lot of speculation there.
Yep. But it's consistent with the facts. He wanted us to find the commandos. He wanted to know who the commandos might've communicated with. One way or another, I think he was plugging a leak.
... And the leak is plugged anyway.
And, as long as I'm out on a limb, I think the only time he was honest with us was when he was talking about island people making deals with the Morganas to protect themselves from the mist.
He was animated then, wasn't he? Children and elderly being vulnerable....
That's even more of a guess than the rest of this, though.
What I'm pretty sure about is that he was sent along to make sure the commandos couldn't talk. If they were dead when we found them, he'd report back and everyone would relax.
You wanted to see me, Capitano?
I just wanted to see how you're feeling.
Bene. The last battle didn't take any vital systems down. I'll be fine.
I wasn't talking about combat damage.
Oh. You're referring to... my emotional state.
That's right.
I know the commandos' deaths... I know it's not my fault. But it's hard. And knowing...
... Take your time.
It's just that having that connection exploited by an agent posing as a "survivor" momentarily confused me.

Fields.MenuText: People can be terrible.
It was a dirty trick, but this is war.
I wish we'd figured it out sooner.

Fields.DialogueText: They can be. I have seen people do many terrible things.
It is a bitter reality.
Next time, perhaps we will.
And yet, Capitano, despite all of it, I remain as optimistic as ever.
Really? Many people would be crushed by deception like that.
There is evil in the world, including Morganas, but there's an abundance of good people, too. You're a prime example.
I'm a prime example of something.
I'm serious! You are a great capitano, savvy and courageous, but our relationship has grown beyond that. I see you as my most loyal friend.
Me too. You're really something else. Thanks, Axum.
Capitano, you are completely and forever welcome!
... I don't really know what to say.
"Completely and forever?" Wow.
Don't be snide.
Sorry. I'm just....
Something about this is still bothering you?
It's just... if my hypothesis is correct, I really wish we knew what those commandos saw. That's all.
Ah. Capisco.
But I'm sure we'll found out eventually, one way or another.
Would another cup of coffee ease your mind?
Heh. Let's find out.
